texts.html: by jackdurden

Recently, I was using the SPGL1 toolbox to recover some “compressed sensed” images. As a reminder, SPGL1 implements the method described in “Probing the Pareto Frontier for basis pursuit solutions” of Michael P. Friedlander and Ewout van den Berg. It solves the Basis Pursuit DeNoise (or ) problem with a error power

texts.html: This problem is particularly well designed for the reconstruction of compressed sensed images since most of them are very sparse in the “gradient basis” (see for instance some references about Compressed Sensing for MRI). Minimizing the TV norm, since performed in the spatial domain, is also sometimes more efficient than minimizing the norm is a particular sparsity basis (e.g. 2-D wavelets, curvelets, …).

texts.html: .

This is somehow related to one of the lessons provided in the TwIST paper (“A new twIst: two-step iterative shrinkage/thresholding algorithms for image restoration”) of J. Bioucas-Dias and M. Figueiredo about the so-called Moreau function : There is a deep link between some iterative resolutions of a regularized BP problem using a given sparsity metric, e.g. the or the TV norm, and the canonic denoising method of this metric, i.e. when the measurement is the identity operator, giving Soft Thresholding or TV denoising respectively.
text: This is somehow related to one of the lessons provided in the
“A new twIst: two-step iterative shrinkage/thresholding algorithms for image restoration”
There is a deep link between some iterative resolutions of a regularized BP problem using a given sparsity metric, e.g. the
or the TV norm, and the canonic denoising method of this metric, i.e. when the measurement is the identity operator, giving Soft Thresholding or TV denoising respectively.

texts.html: Thanks to the implementation of Antonin Chambolle (used also by TwIST), this last canonic TV minimization can be computed very quickly. Therefore, if needed, the required projection on the TV ball above can be also inserted in a potential “SPGL1 for TV sparsity problem”.
text: (used also by TwIST), this last canonic TV minimization can be computed very quickly. Therefore, if needed, the required projection on the TV ball above can be also inserted in a potential “SPGL1 for TV sparsity problem”.

texts.html: 23 Responses to SPGL1 and TV minimization ?
Gabriel Peyré says:

computed.font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', sans-serif

texts.html: August 18, 2008 at 11:42 am
Dear Laurent,

As far as the Lagrangian formulation is concerned, you can replace the iterative thresholding algorithm proposed by so many researcher (including Figueiredo Nowak and Daubechies et al) by proximal iterations, where the soft thresholding is replaced by some inner iterations of Chambolle ROF algorithm (published in JMIV). For more information about proximal iterations (and convergence theorem), you should have a look at recent preprints of Patrick Combettes at Paris 6.
text: As far as the Lagrangian formulation is concerned, you can replace the iterative thresholding algorithm proposed by so many researcher (including Figueiredo Nowak and Daubechies et al) by proximal iterations, where the soft thresholding is replaced by some inner iterations of Chambolle ROF algorithm (published in JMIV). For more information about proximal iterations (and convergence theorem), you should have a look at recent preprints of Patrick Combettes at Paris 6.

texts.html: Intuitively, you just follow the surrogate functional derivation made by Daubechies in her CPAM paper with Defrise and Demol, but replace L1 norm of coefficient in orthobasis by TV norm, which leads to the resolution of the lagrangian ROF.
text: Intuitively, you just follow the surrogate functional derivation made by Daubechies in her CPAM paper with Defrise and Demol, but replace L1 norm of coefficient in orthobasis by TV norm, which leads to the resolution of the lagrangian ROF.

texts.html: Another options is to make the change of variagle v=grad(u) so that the TV-L2 problem becomes a L1-L2 (with complex coefficients as you noticed), and solve with iterative thresholding for v. The issue is that during iterations, you need to impose the constraint rot(v)=0, which requires to solve the poisson equation at each iteration. Works great in practice (its 2 FFTs if you use periodic boundary conditions) !
text: Another options is to make the change of variagle v=grad(u) so that the TV-L2 problem becomes a L1-L2 (with complex coefficients as you noticed), and solve with iterative thresholding for v. The issue is that during iterations, you need to impose the constraint rot(v)=0, which requires to solve the poisson equation at each iteration. Works great in practice (its 2 FFTs if you use periodic boundary conditions) !

texts.html:
Also, in the paper of Chambolle, there is a nice trick to solve for deblurring when the operator is a projection, so it will also work for CS if the matrix is a random projector !
It is a 1 line of code modification of Chambolle algorithm, very nice. At it’s like the fastest algorithm on earth to solve CS-TV
text: Also, in the paper of Chambolle, there is a nice trick to solve for deblurring when the operator is a projection, so it will also work for CS if the matrix is a random projector !
It is a 1 line of code modification of Chambolle algorithm, very nice. At it’s like the fastest algorithm on earth to solve CS-TV

BTW, I think Chambolle’s paper is difficult to find online, but you can get a preprint here
http://www.ceremade.dauphine.fr/preprints/CMD/2002-40.ps.gz
text: BTW, I think Chambolle’s paper is difficult to find online, but you can get a preprint here

texts.html: It is a must read for any one interested by TV minimization. There are two very cool tricks at the end, one to solve the L2 constraint optimization (the lambda of the lagrangian penalization is updated by a simple rule at each iteration) and the other to solve inverse problems with projectors.
text: It is a must read for any one interested by TV minimization. There are two very cool tricks at the end, one to solve the L2 constraint optimization (the lambda of the lagrangian penalization is updated by a simple rule at each iteration) and the other to solve inverse problems with projectors.

texts.html: The paper takes the example of deblurring, but it also works great for TV-inpainting or TV-CS with projection on random fourier subset ! Its is like a 5 lines of matlab code algorithm (once you have grad and div operator implemented somewhere), its converges very fast (its is a fixed point iteration with a speed of convergence).
text: The paper takes the example of deblurring, but it also works great for TV-inpainting or TV-CS with projection on random fourier subset ! Its is like a 5 lines of matlab code algorithm (once you have grad and div operator implemented somewhere), its converges very fast (its is a fixed point iteration with a speed of convergence).

texts.html: August 18, 2008 at 3:43 pm
Dear Jackdurden,

Chambolle’s algorithm solves the regularized TV, but at the end of the paper (section 4), he explains how to update at each step the regularization parameter so that the solution converges to the solution of TV_sigma. You just multiply lambda by sigma/error where error is the L2 error at current step.
text: Chambolle’s algorithm solves the regularized TV, but at the end of the paper (section 4), he explains how to update at each step the regularization parameter so that the solution converges to the solution of TV_sigma. You just multiply lambda by sigma/error where error is the L2 error at current step.

texts.html: Chambolle’s algorithm solve TV denoising (ROF), meaning A=Identity, but at the end of the paper (section 5), he explains how to extend it when A is an orthogonal projector, meaning A A*=Identity (the sensing vectors are orthogonal), which is the case for partial Fourier matrices or orthogonalised gaussian matrices or sub-sampled noiselets or …
text: Chambolle’s algorithm solve TV denoising (ROF), meaning A=Identity, but at the end of the paper (section 5), he explains how to extend it when A is an orthogonal projector, meaning A A*=Identity (the sensing vectors are orthogonal), which is the case for partial Fourier matrices or orthogonalised gaussian matrices or sub-sampled noiselets or …

texts.html:
The idea is to use Chambolle algorithm to denoise an initial image u (you can start by u=0), and at each step of the algorithm, project this image to be denoised on the measurement constraint A* u=y:
u <- u + A* ( y – A u ) (*)
and then you continue using sereral iteration of Chambolle’s algorithm, equation (9) of the paper.
text: The idea is to use Chambolle algorithm to denoise an initial image u (you can start by u=0), and at each step of the algorithm, project this image to be denoised on the measurement constraint A* u=y:
and then you continue using sereral iteration of Chambolle’s algorithm, equation (9) of the paper.

texts.html: So you’ve got two embbeded for loops (one for the update step (*) and then several iteration of Chambolle’s algorithm) but if you solve with sigma=0, you can just do 1 iteration of Chambolle’s algorithm at each step.
text: So you’ve got two embbeded for loops (one for the update step (*) and then several iteration of Chambolle’s algorithm) but if you solve with sigma=0, you can just do 1 iteration of Chambolle’s algorithm at each step.

texts.html: August 19, 2008 at 10:35 am

Chambolle’s algo for CS is a neat idea. I have used it with an ortho projector as proposed by Chambolle to solve an inpainting problem and it’s indeed a single-line of code to modify and worked like a treat ! So it should work very well for CS too provided your measurement matrix is a subsampling of an ortho system. What if it is not exactly an ortho system but “close to” ?
text: Chambolle’s algo for CS is a neat idea. Dear Pierre and Laurent,
Actually yes (if I am not wrong), the algorithm generalizes to the case where A is not an orthogonal projector. You need to replace the orthogonal projection on the constraints Au=b
text: Actually yes (if I am not wrong), the algorithm generalizes to the case where A is not an orthogonal projector. You need to replace the orthogonal projection on the constraints Au=b

texts.html: u <- u + A^+ ( b – A u )
text: u <- u + A^+ ( b – A u )

texts.html: (where A^+=A*  is the pseudo inverse, equal to A* because we are dealing with an orthogonal projector), by a gradient descent step
text: (where A^+=A*  is the pseudo inverse, equal to A* because we are dealing with an orthogonal projector), by a gradient descent step

texts.html: u  than the operator norm of A (same as in the paper of Daubechies et al, and Combettes proved that it can be extended to twice the operator norm).
text: u  than the operator norm of A (same as in the paper of Daubechies et al, and Combettes proved that it can be extended to twice the operator norm).

texts.html: Then you apply Chambolle’s algorithm with a regularization parameter lambda/tau instead of lambda.
text: Then you apply Chambolle’s algorithm with a regularization parameter lambda/tau instead of lambda.

texts.html: This corresponds to proximal iterations, since Chambolle algorithm is actually computing the proximal operator associated to the TV norm.
text: This corresponds to proximal iterations, since Chambolle algorithm is actually computing the proximal operator associated to the TV norm.

texts.html: Intuitively, as emphasized by Laurent, this corresponds to replacing the soft thresholding by the ROF resolution, which are prox operator of respectively the L1 norm in an ortho-basis and the TV norm.
text: Intuitively, as emphasized by Laurent, this corresponds to replacing the soft thresholding by the ROF resolution, which are prox operator of respectively the L1 norm in an ortho-basis and the TV norm.

texts.html: I am not sure wether the update of lambda to match the L2 constraint is still garantied to work in this case.
